Daily Universal Register

Briefing

Bahamas: The Duke and Duchess of Sussexs two-day tour includes engagements to understand the islands Covid response and a junkanoo parade.

Belgium: Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, meets President Biden of the US, with discussions focusing on plans to reduce reliance on Russian energy. Joint press conference afterwards. Biden then travels to Poland to meet President Duda.

India: Subrahmanyam Jaishankar, the foreign minister, is expected to host Wang Yi, his Chinese counterpart who has also been visiting Pakistan and Afghanistan, for talks.

Pakistan: Parliament holds a session to consider a no-confidence motion in Imran Khan, the prime minister, who is accused of mismanagement.

UK: Social Democratic and Labour Party gathers for conference. The meeting comes at a time of enormous political turmoil in Northern Ireland before elections in May, with the Northern Ireland Executive collapsing this month after the resignation of the DUPs Paul Givan as first minister.

On this day

In 1957 the Treaty of Rome was signed, creating the European Economic Community, which came into force on January 1, 1958; in 1969 John Lennon and Yoko Ono began their first honeymoon bed-in for peace, at the Hilton Hotel in Amsterdam, after their wedding on March 20. They invited the press in every day for a week between 9am and 9pm to see them in bed discussing world peace; in 1998 Yoweri Museveni, the president of Uganda, spoke about the transatlantic slave trade to an audience including President Clinton of the US and African leaders, saying: African chiefs were the ones waging war on each other and capturing their own people and selling them. If anyone should apologise it should be the African chiefs. We still have those traitors here even today.

Nature notes

Some bird names are sheer poetry. Take goldeneye. The males black and white body, set off by a domed green head, would make this medium-sized diving duck handsome enough; but its large, yellow eyes turn it into a masterpiece. The female also has the piercing golden eye, but her head is chocolate brown. Like most birds, the goldeneye has a litany of descriptive alternative names. In Lancashire its marine eating habits earned it the title of mussel cracker; in Norfolk, the distinctive whistling sound it produces in flight led to its nicknames of rattle wings and whistler. Roxburgh folk knew the species as the doucker, meaning the one who dives.

Jonathan Tulloch
